DuckDB in R

  • Show All Code
  • Hide All Code
  • View Source

1 Establish a connection to DuckDB

Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(DBI)
library(duckdb)
library(duckplyr)

# to start an in-memory database
con <- dbConnect(duckdb())
# or con <- dbConnect(duckdb(), dbdir = ":memory:")

# to use a database file (not shared between processes)
# con <- dbConnect(duckdb(), dbdir = "my-db.duckdb", read_only = FALSE)
# to use a database file (shared between processes)
# con <- dbConnect(duckdb(), dbdir = "my-db.duckdb", read_only = TRUE)

2 Load data into DuckDB

2.1 Load data from R chunk

Code
# write mtcars, from R environment, to duckdb database
dbWriteTable(con, "mtcars", mtcars) 

# register iris, from R environment, as a view in duckdb
duckdb_register(con, "iris_view", iris) 
duckdb_register(con, "flights", nycflights13::flights)

# read data from local file to duckdb
duckdb_read_csv(con, "gdp", "data/gdp.csv", na.strings = "NA")

2.2 Load data from sql chunk

Code
create table gdp2 as
select * from read_csv('data/gdp.csv')

2.3 Show tables in DuckDB

  • list tables in R chunk
Code
dbListTables(con) 
[1] "flights"   "gdp"       "gdp2"      "iris_view" "mtcars"
  • list tables in sql connection chunk
Code
show tables
5 records
name
flights
gdp
gdp2
iris_view
mtcars

3 Query data from DuckDB

3.1 Oder of query execution

Please visit SQL Query Order for more information.

3.2 View the whole table

Code
SELECT * FROM gdp

3.3 More complex queries

Code
select * from mtcars
where hp > 100
order by -hp
Displaying records 1 - 10
mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb

15.2 8 275.8 180 3.07 3.780 18.00 0 0 3 3

We can omit Select * in the query in duckdb as it is the default.

Code
from mtcars
where hp > 100
order by -hp
Displaying records 1 - 10
mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb

We can anti-select columns in the query in duckdb as shown below.

Code
from flights
select * exclude (year, month, day)
where month = 1 and day = 1
order by dep_delay desc
limit 10
Displaying records 1 - 10

More complex queries can be written in sql chunk as shown below.

Code
SELECT *
FROM (
   SELECT
     tailnum,
    COUNT(*) AS count,
    AVG(distance) AS dist,
    AVG(arr_delay) AS delay
  FROM flights
  GROUP BY tailnum
) q01
WHERE (count > 20.0) AND (dist < 2000.0) AND (NOT((delay IS NULL)))
limit 10
Displaying records 1 - 10
tailnum count dist delay
N708JB 246 1389.9959 8.5126050
N535UW 60 1669.4000 2.1333333
N33289 119 1420.7395 2.4621849
N3GKAA 77 1246.5974 4.9733333
N75435 89 1760.4831 4.9438202
N3EKAA 45 1186.7778 0.2444444
N562JB 315 1243.7810 10.9903846
N37456 89 1634.2022 -7.8409091
N625JB 275 1463.5709 7.1102941
N789SW 30 967.3667 9.9655172

4 Save outcome of query into R environment

We can save the outcome of the query into the R environment as shown below1.

Code
SELECT tailnum, AVG(distance) AS dist, AVG(arr_delay) AS delay
FROM flights
WHERE month = 1
GROUP BY tailnum
HAVING COUNT(*) > 20
ORDER BY delay DESC
LIMIT 10

The outcome of the query is saved in the R environment as top10_delayed_planes and we can call it in R chunk as shown below.

Code
top10_delayed_planes |> 
  gt() |> 
  tab_options(table.width = pct(90),
              column_labels.font.size = 16,
              column_labels.font.weight = "bold",
              column_labels.text_transform = "capitalize") |>
  opt_row_striping()
tailnum dist delay
N21144 601.4286 59.10000
N14920 423.9048 52.28571
N517MQ 590.0968 51.40000
N21537 529.1111 50.40741
N10575 485.4000 48.10714
N13994 476.0294 47.90625
N16546 519.8800 46.36000
N13553 482.7429 43.33333
N13958 442.8400 43.00000
N11565 442.1538 40.08333

Why bother with duckdb when we can do the same in R? The answer is that duckdb is faster than R for large datasets. For example, the vdemdata dataset has 500 V-Dem indicators and 245 indices + 57 other indicators from other data sources. It is a huge dataset and it is almost impossible to view the whole V-Dem dataset in R. It would be better, although still quite slow, to use duckdb to query the dataset and view the outcome in R.

5 Disconnect from DuckDB

Code
dbDisconnect(con, shutdown = TRUE)
Back to top

Footnotes

  1. Please go to upper right corner to view the source code.

Source Code
---
title: DuckDB in R
format:
  aps-html:
    code-tools: true

## Establish a connection to DuckDB

```{r}
#| label: setup
#| message: false
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(DBI)
library(duckdb)
library(duckplyr)

# to start an in-memory database
con <- dbConnect(duckdb())
# or con <- dbConnect(duckdb(), dbdir = ":memory:")

# to use a database file (not shared between processes)
# con <- dbConnect(duckdb(), dbdir = "my-db.duckdb", read_only = FALSE)
# to use a database file (shared between processes)
# con <- dbConnect(duckdb(), dbdir = "my-db.duckdb", read_only = TRUE)
```

## Load data into DuckDB

### Load data from `R` chunk

```{r}
# write mtcars, from R environment, to duckdb database
dbWriteTable(con, "mtcars", mtcars) 

# register iris, from R environment, as a view in duckdb
duckdb_register(con, "iris_view", iris) 
duckdb_register(con, "flights", nycflights13::flights)

# read data from local file to duckdb
duckdb_read_csv(con, "gdp", "data/gdp.csv", na.strings = "NA")
```

### Load data from `sql` chunk

```{sql connection=con}
create table gdp2 as
select * from read_csv('data/gdp.csv')
```

### Show tables in DuckDB

-   list tables in `R` chunk

```{r}
dbListTables(con) 
```

-   list tables in `sql connection` chunk

```{sql connection=con}
show tables
```

## Query data from DuckDB

### Oder of query execution

![](../fig/sql_query_order.webp)

Please visit [SQL Query Order](https://lukianovihor.medium.com/sql-order-of-query-execution-8c7cd926400) for more information.

### View the whole table

```{sql connection=con}
SELECT * FROM gdp
```

### More complex queries

```{sql connection=con}
select * from mtcars
where hp > 100
order by -hp
```

We can omit `Select *` in the query in `duckdb` as it is the default.

```{sql connection=con}
from mtcars
where hp > 100
order by -hp
```

We can anti-select columns in the query in `duckdb` as shown below.

```{sql connection=con}
from flights
select * exclude (year, month, day)
where month = 1 and day = 1
order by dep_delay desc
limit 10
```

More complex queries can be written in `sql` chunk as shown below.

```{sql connection=con}
SELECT *
FROM (
   SELECT
     tailnum,
    COUNT(*) AS count,
    AVG(distance) AS dist,
    AVG(arr_delay) AS delay
  FROM flights
  GROUP BY tailnum
) q01
WHERE (count > 20.0) AND (dist < 2000.0) AND (NOT((delay IS NULL)))
limit 10
```

## Save outcome of query into R environment

We can save the outcome of the query into the R environment as shown below[^1].

[^1]: Please go to upper right corner to view the source code.

```{sql connection=con, output.var="top10_delayed_planes"}
SELECT tailnum, AVG(distance) AS dist, AVG(arr_delay) AS delay
FROM flights
WHERE month = 1
GROUP BY tailnum
HAVING COUNT(*) > 20
ORDER BY delay DESC
LIMIT 10
```

```{r}
#| include: false
nycflights13::flights %>%
  filter(month == 1) %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 20) %>%
  summarise(dist = mean(distance, na.rm = TRUE),
            delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  arrange(desc(delay)) %>%
  head(10)
```

The outcome of the query is saved in the R environment as `top10_delayed_planes` and we can call it in R chunk as shown below.

```{r}
top10_delayed_planes |> 
  gt() |> 
  tab_options(table.width = pct(90),
              column_labels.font.size = 16,
              column_labels.font.weight = "bold",
              column_labels.text_transform = "capitalize") |>
  opt_row_striping()
```

Why bother with `duckdb` when we can do the same in `R`?
The answer is that `duckdb` is faster than `R` for large datasets.
For example, the `vdemdata` dataset has 500 V-Dem indicators and 245 indices + 57 other indicators from other data sources.
It is a huge dataset and it is almost impossible to view the whole V-Dem dataset in R.
It would be better, although still quite slow, to use `duckdb` to query the dataset and view the outcome in R.

## Disconnect from DuckDB

```{r}
dbDisconnect(con, shutdown = TRUE)
```
